titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Special Collections, Signature Letters
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Special Collections, Signature Letters FA1480

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-04 05:35:20 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Special Collections, Signature Letters

physdesc.extent:
15 boxes
(12 legal document containers, 2 letter document containers, 1 15x11 oversize box)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necesary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in 2018 by the Ford Foundation and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2018:060.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains letters written by significant individuals to Ford Foundation staff between 1943-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into four series.
The collection arrangement is as follows:
Series 1. Letters from Famous People A-Z, 1937-1987

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Finding aids concerning Ford Foundation correspondence with famous individuals and public figures include:

p.extref: FA1411 Ford Foundation records, Correspondence with United States Senators and Representatives
FA718 Ford Foundation records, American Literary Manuscripts (ALM) collection

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard processing by Katie Martin and Darren Young, November 2018

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The original order of the letters was retained at the time of processing. Individual files are arranged neither alphabetically nor chronologically, but the additional description note can help locate the first instance of an individual's letters within a file.

Dulski, Don Fuqua, Manuel Lujan, Clarence Miller, John Culver, Thomas Foley, John Rhodes, John Anderson, Robert Mathias, Sam Gibbons, Bob Eckhardt, Neal Smith, Parren Mitchell, Silvio Conte, Edward Koch, James O'Hara, William Ford, Edward Biester, Jr., Torbert H. Macdonald, David Obey, Lucien Nedzi, Al Ullman, Daniel Flood, John Conyers, Patsy Mink, Peter Frelinghuysen, Guy Vander Jagt, Fred Rooney, Robert Drinan, Michael Harrington, Louis Stokes, James Stanton, George Collins, Thomas O'Neill, Jr., William Steiger, Sidney Yates, Jerome Waldie, Brock Adams, Thomas Rees, Albert Quie, Barber Conable, B.F. Sisk

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the letters within this series were organized by the Ford Foundation into individual folders that describe the letter's author, addressee, date, extent, and point of origin on the front cover.

The last group of files in the series contains correspondence that was grouped with this series' signature letters but for the most part, was not organized in the same way as the other letters. Ford may have been in the process of preparing these letters to fit into its established system of arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the lead up to the passing of the 1969 Tax Act, the House Ways and Means Committee, chaired by Representative Wilbur Mills, requested that Ford Foundation President McGeorge Bundy appear before the committee. He was asked to explain what some saw as political bias in recent Ford Foundation grants. Among the controversial programs were grants to the Cleveland Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) and the Southern Regional Council for voter registration activities, the travel and study awards to Robert Kennedy's staff following his assassination, and support for the Yale Law School's League for Environmental Law.

This series contains correspondence, press releases, and summaries related to 12 of the 19 controversial grants. Materials were originally in a binder but were removed and placed into folders for preservation purposes. The original order was retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 8. Urban Training Center for Christian Missions
10. League for Environmental Law (Yale Law School)
12. United States National Student Association Grant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize materials signed by Ronald Reagan
